auction_quick_facts.Exterior Color: Ireland Dark Green Metallic/Rocky Mountains Light Brown Metallic

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/35P67PV.dougs_take: The Maybach 62 is one of the greatest luxury car bargains out there. These were VERY expensive new, and they were built with an interior that's still considered highly luxurious by modern standards – but nearly two decades worth of depreciation has brought them within the reach of a much wider audience. This Maybach is finished in a gorgeous color combination, it boasts relatively low mileage, AND it's unmodified – so it ticks many of the right boxes. The clean, accident-free Carfax report should give bidders valuable peace of mind, too – and, like every 62, this one touts a big, twin-turbocharged V12 rated at 543 horsepower. These hard to find as the smaller 57 outsold the 62 by a wide margin, and I'm happy to offer this example on Cars & Bids.
auction_highlights: This long-wheelbase sedan's odometer displays about 50,400 miles.
The attached Carfax history report lists no accidents or mileage inconsistencies in this car's past.

Factory equipment includes 18-inch wheels, a glass sunroof, an electronic rear door closing mechanism, wood interior trim, heated, ventilated, and power-adjustable front seats, heated, ventilated, and power-adjustable rear seats with extending footrests, ambient lighting, a 21-speaker Bose surround sound system, a rear-seat entertainment system, and adaptive cruise control, according to a build sheet pictured in the gallery. The selling dealer reports no modifications.

Former Mercedes-Benz parent company Daimler resurrected the Maybach name for the 2002 model year to compete against Bentley and Rolls-Royce. The range included a short- and a long-wheelbase sedan called 57 and 62, respectively. Sales in the United States totaled 244 units in 2004, and the bigger, more expensive 62 represented about a quarter of that figure. Daimler axed the Maybach brand in 2013, though the name survives as a trim level in the S-Class line-up today.
Power comes from a twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V12, rated at 543 horsepower and 664 lb-ft of torque. It spins the rear wheels via a 5-speed automatic transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9l5RMpY.dougs_take: I love the ZJ Jeep Grand Cherokee in general, but these 5.9 Limited models were extra special, as they came with the big Magnum V8 under the hood and a more luxurious interior – and they were only available for the 1998 model year. This particular 5.9 Limited is especially desirable, as it's an unmodified, one-owner example with 4-wheel drive and just 61,500 miles on the odometer – a remarkable discovery! This Grand Cherokee also boasts some great factory equipment, including heated front seats, a set of unique 16-inch wheels – and the cool vented hood and mesh grille, making it stand out from other ZJs – and it touts a clean, accident-free Carfax report. These were the Trackhawks of their era, and I’m proud to offer this one on Cars & Bids!
auction_highlights: The odometer on this Jeep currently displays about 61,500 miles.
The attached Carfax history report has a few gaps but shows no accidents for the given time period. It also confirms that this is a 1-owner car.

According to the window sticker provided in the gallery, factory equipment includes 16-inch wheels, a sunroof, a roof rack, leather upholstery, heated and power-adjustable front seats, cruise control, and more as described below. The seller reports no modifications.

Jeep's "ZJ" chassis was offered in base, Laredo, and range-topping Limited trim levels, along with a few special production models over its five-year production run. The 5.9 Limited package, as seen on this particular ZJ, brought the biggest engine ever fitted to a Grand Cherokee at the time, which made this family hauler the quickest SUV of its day. According to production numbers from Jeep, approximately 14,000 1998 Jeep Grand Cherokee Limited 5.9 models were produced. It remains a popular choice among Jeep enthusiasts and collectors.

Power comes from a 5.9-liter V8, rated at 245 horsepower and 345 lb-ft of torque. Output is sent to all four wheels through a 4-speed automatic transmission and Jeep's Quadra-Trac full-time four-wheel drive system with low range.
